--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@c...> wrote:
> I would also like to announce a new NEAT simulation; The Artificial
Ant. 
> From my page: 
> 
> "The articial ant is a classic benchmark used in GA / GP. The goal
is to 
> steer an articial ant (red and black) over a mostly empty (white) 
> toroidal world where there is a trail of food (green). If the ant
finds 
> a piece of food (a red square above), it's given a point. If it
steps 
> without finding any food (black), it simply wastes one of it's
turns. 
> When it's been allowed to run for a number of steps, it's killed
off. 
> The fitness is the number of food pieces it has found."
> 
> It uses two inputs bias and "food ahead" - an indicator that
detarmines 
> if there is food ahead of the ant or not. It uses four outputs, 
> MoveForward, TurnLeft, TurnRight and EatUnderneath. It picks the
one 
> that firest "hardest".
> 
> The successrate isn't quite there yet, but it does find perfect 
> solutions. GP solves this one quite easily, but in GP, it's much
easier 
> to solve the problem of an order list of instructions. As in "under 
> these conditions, perform these instructions "x,y,z". In GP, this
is 
> inherent in the system. NEAT has to evolve it.
> 
> I kinda feel that the inputs/outputs aren't exactly fair to NEAT.
Could 
> anyone suggest some inputs/outputs that would suit NEAT better, but 
> wouldn't violate the Artificial Ant premise?
> 

It doesn't sound terribly unfair to me.  So if I understand correctly,
for NEAT this is a memory-intensive problem, since its context
includes where it's recently been, so it has to use recurrency to keep
the current state up to date.  Would you agree with this?

Some comments on outputs:  Can you let it fire both turn and move at
the same time?  That may make more sense from the network's
perspective, for example if something is to its left, so it doesn't
have to take two steps to get there.  Also, what is the purpose of the
EatUnderneath output?  It seems like it doesn't add anything to the
problem...why not just have it automatically "eat" if it has food
under it?  It seems that having to call EatUnderneath adds a lot of
complexity to the problem for NEAT since its context doesn't change at
all when it does this, but it has to do different things in a row,
i.e. eat, and then move.

ken
